Title.evidence: Methods: This randomized trial included patients with symptomatic haemorrhoids treated in Shanghai from May 2018 to September 2021.

Trial_Design.evidence: Eligible patients were randomly 1:1 assigned the modified ligation procedure for prolapsed haemorrhoids (MLPPH) and SH groups.

Participants.evidence: This randomized trial included patients with symptomatic haemorrhoids treated in Shanghai from May 2018 to September 2021.

Intervention.evidence: Eligible patients were randomly 1:1 assigned the modified ligation procedure for prolapsed haemorrhoids (MLPPH) and SH groups.

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to compare a modified ligation procedure versus stapled haemorrhoidectomy (SH) in patients with symptomatic haemorrhoids.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the assessment of efficacy at 6 months after the intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Eligible patients were randomly 1:1 assigned the modified ligation procedure for prolapsed haemorrhoids (MLPPH) and SH groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Out of 187 patients screened, 133 patients were randomized (67 for MLPPH and 66 for SH).

Number_Analysed.evidence: One patient in the MLPPH group was excluded, and two patients were lost to follow-up.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean operating time was longer in MLPPH than in SH (57.42 min versus 30.68 min; P < 0.001).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Registration number: Chinese Clinical Trial Registry ChiCTR1800015928 ( http://www.chictr.org.cn/searchproj.aspx ).
